results.title: In pursuit of the possible
results.creator_credit: Ian Host, Alistair Innes and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
Moderated by Geoffrey Robertson, this program examines, by means of hypothetical situations, the role that Australia can play in meeting the challenges posed by disarmament and arms control. The program has been divided into three parts to facilitate its use by community and educational groups and to permit discussion of the various issues as they arise.

results.title: Does Dracula have Aids?
results.creator_credit: John Lander, Ken Chown and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
AIDS is the most publicised and least understood disease in Australia. This video may help to clear up some of the confusion as the discoverer of the AIDS virus, Professor Luc Montagnier, joins Australia’s most experienced AIDS specialists and community leaders to confront the ethical and social dilemmas created by the disease. Geoffrey Robertson’s Hypothetical on AIDS was filmed on 12th August, 1986.

results.title: Blood on the wattle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
Focuses on the importance and relevance of the Australian Constitution to its citizens. Apart from looking at its origins, and other constitutional models, this kit explores the implications of making changes to the Australian Constitution. Based on one of “Geoffrey Robertson’s Hypotheticals” entitled “Blood on the wattle”. Also includes a post-hypothetical discussion of the Constitution by the panellists.

results.title: Heather's case (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Improving Performance”.
The youngest clerical worker in a project team is angry about staff who are inconsiderate, messy and who avoid her whilst her colleagues have complained to the new supervisor about her being aggressive. The supervisor attempts to resolve the problem and then Peter Quarry assumes the role of supervisor and uses the 3 step approach.

results.title: Nature or Nurture (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Diversity”.
Congenital dislocation of the hip in humans is caused by both genetic and environmental factors, and by the interaction between them. Illustrates the methodology involved in sorting out the different factors

results.title: Physical growth and motor development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human development: the first 2 1/2 years”.
Emphasises individual differences by depicting a wide range of normal physical growth and motor development. Discusses ways in which environmental factors such as nutrition and the mother’s health habits during pregnancy affect development. Traces developmental patterns and norms by examining the role of crawling in simultaneously developing both parts of the brain and the sequences of development across cultures and between genders.

results.title: Cognitive development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human development: the first 2 1/2 years”.
Cognition involves the acquiring and use of knowledge. From birth, infants must learn how to learn and develop their senses, memory and perception. This episode discusses the stages of cognitive development as well as examining the theories of Piaget, the roles of recognition and receptive memory and the effect of stimulation in developing cognitive skills.

results.title: Language development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human development: the first 2 1/2 years”.
This episode looks at how young infants acquire language. Chomsky’s theories about innate language competencies are examined as are the theories of operative conditioning and modelling where environment rather than herditary factors are seen to be more influential in the process of language acquisition. Babies use talking movements from birth and the program illustrates the processes whereby “babbling” becomes articulate speech.
